qas.question: In taxonomies, what type of group are flowering plants treated?
What do the Wettstein and Engler systems use at the assigned rank of subdivision?
How does the APG system of 1998, with its 2003 and 2009 revisions, treat flowering plants?
What formal subclass classification were flowering plants given in 2009?
What are coherent groups not linked to?
What do Anthophyta and Magnoliophytina use as the assigned rank of subdivision?

plausible_answers.text: as a clade called angiosperms without a formal botanical name

qas.question: How does the APG system of 1996 treat flowering plants?
What taxonomy was published alongside the 2003 revision?

context: In most taxonomies, the flowering plants are treated as a <a0_0>coherent<a0_0/> group. The most popular descriptive name has been Angiospermae (Angiosperms), with Anthophyta <b9_0>("<a1_0>flowering plants<a1_0/>")<b9_0/> a second choice. These names are not linked to <b5_0>any rank<b5_0/>. The Wettstein system and the Engler system use the name <a2_0><b6_0>Angiospermae<b6_0/><a2_0/>, at the assigned rank of subdivision. The Reveal system treated flowering plants as subdivision Magnoliophytina (Frohne & U. Jensen ex Reveal, Phytologia 79: 70 1996), but later split it to Magnoliopsida, Liliopsida, and Rosopsida. The Takhtajan system and Cronquist system treat this group at the rank of division, leading to the name Magnoliophyta (from the family name Magnoliaceae). The Dahlgren system and Thorne system (1992) treat this group at the rank of class, leading to the name Magnoliopsida. The APG system of 1998, and the later 2003 and 2009 revisions, treat the flowering plants <b7_0>as <a3_0>a clade called angiosperms<a3_0/> without a formal botanical name<b7_0/>. However, <b8_0>a formal classification<b8_0/> was published alongside the 2009 revision in which the flowering plants form the Subclass <a4_0>Magnoliidae<a4_0/>.
